@graph.reasoning: Opinion of the Court this expansion of the refusal to deal beyond the targeted transaction that gives great coercive force to a commercial boycott: unrelated transactions are used as leverage to achieve the terms desired.

involvedParties: Eastern States Retail Lumber Dealers' Assn.
@graph.reasoning: Recognized in the antitrust field as one of the "leading case[s] involving commercial boycotts."

@graph.@id: Paramount Famous Lasky Corp. v. United States, 282 U. S. 30 (1930)
@graph.reasoning: Unreasonable an agreement among competing motion picture distributors under which they refused to license films to exhibitors except on standardized terms.

@graph.@id: Anderson v. Shipowners Assn. of Pacific Coast, 272 U. S. 359 (1926)
@graph.reasoning: Unreasonable restraint of trade in which an association of employers attempted to establish industry-wide terms of employment.

@graph.@id: United States v. Frankfort Distilleries, Inc., 324 U. S. 293 (1945)
@graph.reasoning: Refusal to engage in all transactions with targeted companies unless they agreed to defendants' price-fixing scheme.
